Kapal Pesiar Ini Anti Mabuk Laut, Jamin Pelayaran Mulus
07 Nov 2019, 09:00 by Ahmad Masaul Khoiri


Kapal Pesiar X-Bow yang anti mabuk laut. (Foto: Aurora Expeditions/CNN)

Jakarta - Salah satu alasan utama beberapa orang enggan berlibur menggunakan kapal pesiar adalah mabuk laut. Nah, sebuah terobosan bikin kapal bisa berlayar lebih mulus sehingga penumpang tak mabuk laut.Diberitakan CNN, Rabu (6/11/2019), kapal pesiar baru itu bernama X-Bow. Ulstein, sebuah perusahaan pembuat kapal yang berbasis di Norwegia, telah mendesain kapal agar para penumpangnya tidak mengalami mual dan bisa menjelajah dengan lebih lancar.Tidak seperti kapal tradisional yang bergerak naik dan turun saat melintasi ombak, X-Bow menembusnya. Energinya disebarkan ke sisi-sisi kapal.Dengan kata lain hanya tersisa sedikit goyangan sehingga berimbas mengurangi potensi mabuk laut. Efek dari hantaman kuat yang dirasakan setelah menembus gelombang laut pun juga hilang.Kapal X-Bow pertama yang muncul adalah Greg Mortimer oleh Aurora Expeditions. Spesialisasi pelayarannya ke Antartika. Namanya terinspirasi salah satu orang Australia pertama yang mendaki Gunung Everest, kapal ini telah berangkat dari Ushaia, Argentina, pada 31 Oktober lalu.X-Bow dijajal menyeberangi Drake Passage, selat antara Amerika Selatan dan Antartika dan dikenal sebagai persilangan yang berbahaya bahkan bagi pelaut yang paling berpengalaman sekalipun. Victoria Primrose, kepala pemasaran dan timnya di Aurora ingin menjajalnya di sana.Desain yang berbeda dari X-Bow memerlukan pemikiran ulang di dalam penataan interior kapal. Tidak ada dek di dan kemudian dibangunlah 'sayap kecil' di samping dan di depan sehingga penumpang dapat melihat pemandangan di sekitarnya.Pelayaran perdana kapal pesiar Greg Mortimer direncanakan selama 12 hari. Namun, Aurora Expeditions menawarkan rencana perjalanan yang lebih panjang di mana para tamu juga dapat mengunjungi Kepulauan Falkland.Antartika sendiri memiliki aturan kunjungan yang cukup ketat, termasuk tak banyak orang yang boleh mengunjunginya. Hal ini turut membuat kapal pesiar Greg Mortimer hanya memiliki 122 tempat tidur.Kabin itu cukup untuk 100 penumpang, batas harian maksimum di Antartika, dan sisanya adalah kru. Hanya ada satu restoran, awak serta penumpang makan bersama yang menciptakan perasaan kedekatan di atas kapal.Simak Video "Kapal Pesiar Greenpeace di Jakarta"[Gambas:Video 20detik](msl/krs)

This Cruise Ship Is Anti-Sea Sickness, Guarantees Seamless Sailing
Nov 7 2019, 09:00 by Ahmad Masaul Khoiri


X-Bow Cruise Ship that is anti seasick. (Photo: Aurora Expeditions / CNN)

Jakarta - One of the main reasons some people are reluctant to vacation on a cruise is sea sickness. Well, a breakthrough made the ship sail more smoothly so that passengers were not seasick. It was reported by CNN, Wednesday (11/06/2019), the new cruise ship was named X-Bow. Ulstein, a shipbuilding company based in Norway, has designed the ship so that its passengers do not experience nausea and can roam more smoothly. Unlike traditional ships that move up and down when crossing the waves, X-Bow penetrates it. The energy is spread to the sides of the ship. In other words, there is only a slight shake so that the impact reduces the potential for seasickness. The effect of the strong impact felt after breaking through the ocean waves was also lost. The first X-Bow ship that emerged was Greg Mortimer by Aurora Expeditions. Specializes in his voyage to Antarctica. His name was inspired by one of the first Australians to climb Mount Everest, this ship departed from Ushaia, Argentina, on 31 October. most experienced though. Victoria Primrose, head of marketing and her team at Aurora wanted to try it there. A different design from X-Bow requires rethinking in the interior arrangement of the ship. There was no deck on and then a 'small wing' was built on the side and front so that passengers could see the surrounding scenery. The first cruise of the cruise ship Greg Mortimer was planned for 12 days. However, Aurora Expeditions offers longer travel plans where guests can also visit the Falkland Islands. Antarctica itself has fairly strict visiting rules, including not many people who can visit it. This helped make Greg Mortimer's cruise ship only have 122 beds. The cabin was enough for 100 passengers, the maximum daily limit in Antarctica, and the rest were crew. There is only one restaurant, the crew and passengers eat together which creates a feeling of closeness on the ship.
